title: 107_s1572
content: The Act may be cited as the "Freedom Consolidation Act of 2001". Congress finds that full and active participants in the Partnership for Peace should be invited to become full NATO members, as stated in previous Acts. This includes the prompt admission of certain countries to NATO to promote economic stability and security in the region. Congress called for the prompt admission of Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, and Slovenia to NATO, and emphasized the importance of including emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe in the enlargement process. At the Madrid Summit of the NATO Alliance in July 1997, Poland, Hungary, and the Czech Republic were invited to join as full members. Congress also highlighted the importance of including Romania, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, and Bulgaria in NATO to enhance stability, freedom, and peace in Europe. At the Madrid Summit of the NATO Alliance in July 1997, Poland, Hungary, and the Czech Republic were invited to join as full members, with the expectation of further invitations to nations willing and able to meet membership criteria. At the 1999 NATO Summit, it was declared that NATO will continue to welcome new members who can uphold the Treaty's principles and contribute to peace and security in the Euro-Atlantic area. No European democratic country fulfilling the Treaty's objectives will be excluded from consideration for membership. In late 2002, NATO will hold a summit in Prague, Czech Republic, to decide on inviting additional emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe to join the Alliance in the next round of NATO enlargement. In May 2000, foreign ministers of several countries declared their cooperation in seeking NATO membership. In May 2000, foreign ministers of several Eastern European countries declared cooperation in seeking NATO membership, later joined by Croatia. President George W. Bush emphasized the importance of security and freedom for all European democracies in a speech in Warsaw in June 2001. President George W. Bush emphasized the importance of NATO membership for all European democracies seeking security and freedom in a speech in Warsaw in June 2001. He advocated for equal opportunities for new democracies from the Baltic to the Black Sea to join NATO and rejected using nations as pawns in political agendas. Former President William J. Clinton emphasized NATO's commitment to remaining open to all European democracies willing to take on membership responsibilities during a speech in Detroit in October 1996. He rejected the idea of excluding nations or allowing a gray zone of insecurity to reemerge in Europe. Congress reaffirms its support for the continued enlargement of the NATO Alliance, as expressed in previous acts and declarations. It endorses the vision of further NATO enlargement articulated by Presidents George W. Bush and William J. Clinton, urging NATO allies to work towards this goal at the Prague Summit in 2002. Designation of Slovakia to receive assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994. Slovakia is designated as eligible to receive assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994, in addition to other countries already designated for assistance under similar acts. The Czech Republic, Slovenia, Romania, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, and Bulgaria are designated as eligible to receive assistance under specific acts, with the possibility for other emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe to also receive assistance. SEC. 5. Authorization of security assistance for countries designated under the NATO Participation Act of 1994. Authorization of Foreign Military Financing for several countries including Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Slovakia, Slovenia, Bulgaria, and Romania for fiscal year 2002. Authorization of Foreign Military Financing for Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Slovakia, Slovenia, Bulgaria, and Romania for fiscal year 2002 includes specific grant amounts allocated for each country, with Slovenia receiving $10,000,000, Bulgaria receiving $10,000,000, and Romania receiving $11,500,000. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to section 515 of the Security Assistance Act of 2000.
